unnormalised: **Yoga Practices: My Journey from Stiff to Supple (and Saner!)**
normalised: So many people ask me about my yoga practice. Honestly, it's been a transformative journey, starting more out of desperation than inspiration! Back in two thousand and eighteen, I was working ten hour days at my I T job in Bangalore, hunched over a computer. My back was killing me, I was stressed beyond belief, and my doctor, Doctor Sharma, seriously suggested I consider yoga.

unnormalised: So many people ask me about my yoga practice. Honestly, it's been a transformative journey, starting more out of desperation than inspiration! Back in 2018, I was working 10-hour days at my IT job in Bangalore, hunched over a computer. My back was killing me, I was stressed beyond belief, and my doctor, Dr. Sharma, seriously suggested I consider yoga.
normalised: Initially, I was skeptical. I thought yoga was just for flexible people. I, on the other hand, could barely touch my toes! But I signed up for a beginner's class at a local studio near Jayanagar, Bangalore – "Om Shanti Yoga" – starting on first january two thousand and nineteen.

unnormalised: Initially, I was skeptical. I thought yoga was just for flexible people. I, on the other hand, could barely touch my toes! But I signed up for a beginner's class at a local studio near Jayanagar, Bangalore – "Om Shanti Yoga" – starting on 01/01/2019.
normalised: The first few classes were humbling. I could barely hold the Downward Dog for more than thirty seconds without collapsing! But slowly, steadily, I started noticing changes. My back pain lessened. I felt calmer, more focused. I even managed to finally nail that headstand I’d been dreading around six A M every morning!

unnormalised: The first few classes were humbling. I could barely hold the Downward Dog for more than 30 seconds without collapsing! But slowly, steadily, I started noticing changes. My back pain lessened. I felt calmer, more focused. I even managed to finally nail that headstand I’d been dreading around 06:00 AM every morning!
normalised: Now, I practice almost daily, even if it's just for twenty minutes before my family wakes up. I usually do a mix of Hatha and Yin yoga, focusing on breathwork (pranayama) learned during a weekend retreat I attended at Isha Yoga Center in Coimbatore on fifteenth march two thousand and twenty. It's not just about the physical postures (asanas); it's about connecting with yourself, finding that inner peace that helps you navigate the chaos of everyday life in India. Believe me, navigating Bangalore traffic at nine hundred hours requires a zen-like calm! Yoga gave me that.
